facts.text: This is an appeal by certificate from the judgment of the High Court of Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment of the High Court of Allahabad reversing the decision of a single Judge of that Court directing the issue of a writ of Mandamus against the respondents under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant was the lessee of a right to collect tolls from persons, vehicles etc., crossing the river by public ferry at Pipraghat, District Ballia.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant who was at the relevant time the lessee of a right to collect tolls from persons, vehicles etc., crossing the river by public ferry at Pipraghat, District Ballia

facts.text: There is a ferry at the village Pipraghat, district Ballia for crossing the river.

anchor.surface_text: In order to appreciate the points a few facts need to be stated. There is a ferry at the village Pipragbat, district Ballia for crossing the river and the right to collect tolls

facts.text: The right to collect tolls in respect of that ferry is put to public auction annually.

anchor.surface_text: the right to collect tolls in respect of that ferry is put to public auction annually. The highest bidder at the auction gets the right.

facts.text: The appellant was the highest bidder for the year 1954 and the licence fee payable by him was Rs. 31,751/-

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the highest bidder for the year 1954 and the licence fee payable by him was Rs. 31,751/-. The practice right upto 1954 was to allow

facts.text: The practice right upto 1954 was to allow the lessee to collect a toll of Rs. 5-1-0 from every stage carriage bus.

anchor.surface_text: The practice right upto 1954 was to allow the lessee to collect a toll of Rs. 5-1-0 from every stage carriage bus. Till March 9 of that year only privately

facts.text: Till March 9, 1954 only privately owned stage carriage buses used to ply on the route.

anchor.surface_text: Till March 9 of that year only privately owned stage carriage buses used to ply on the route in which the ferry crossing was comprised.

facts.text: Thereafter the route has been taken over by the Roadways Department of the State of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the route has been taken over by the Roadways Department of the State of Uttar Pradesh. From March 9 to March 16, the appellant realised tolls

facts.text: From March 9 to March 16, 1954, the appellant realised tolls at Rs. 5.1-0 from the State-owned stage carriage buses.

anchor.surface_text: From March 9 to March 16, the appellant realised tolls at Rs. 5.1-0 from the State-owned stage carriage buses when he was informed by a letter

facts.text: Appellant was informed by a letter by the first respondent that he should allow the Roadways buses to use the ferry on credit till March 31, 1954 and submit bill thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: when he was informed by a letter by the first respondent that he should allow the Roadways buses to use the ferry for crossing and recrossing the river on credit till March 31, 1954

facts.text: The appellant submitted his bill to the Roadways Department on March 31, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: and submitted his bill to the Roadways Department on March 31, 1954. That bill was, however, not paid.

facts.text: The bill was not paid.

anchor.surface_text: That bill was, however, not paid. On April 1, 1954 he received two communications from respondent number 1

facts.text: On April 1, 1954 appellant received communications from respondent 1: no toll leviable on Roadways vehicles and to pay monthly installment without deduction.

anchor.surface_text: On April 1, 1954 he received two communications from respondent number 1 by one of which hi  was informed that not toll is leviable on the Roadways vehicles

facts.text: Appellant moved the High Court of Allahabad under Art. 226 for writ directing respondents to refrain from precluding charging tolls, allow abatement, interim stay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had moved the High Court of Allahabad.under Art. 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ directing the respondent to refrain from precluding the petitioner from charging tolls

facts.text: Before the petition was decided the appellants licence had run out.

anchor.surface_text: Before the petition was decided the appellants licence had run out and, therefore, at the hearing the appellant confined himself to one relief

facts.text: Learned single Judge directed issue of writ for abatement under third paragraph of s.15 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge of the High Court who decided the petition in the first instance came to the conclusion that the appellant was entitled to abatement

facts.text: Respondents preferred appeal under Letters Patent, heard by Division Bench of Allahabad HC.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents preferred an appeal under the Letters Patent which was heard by a Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court.

facts.text: Division Bench held licensee not entitled to abatement unless declaration under s.15 after grant of licence; GO 1946/17-,51 dated December 11, 1951 prior.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held that a licensee is not entitled to abatement of rent unless the Government makes a declaration under s.15 of the Act subsequent to the grant

facts.text: G.O. No. 1946/17-,51 dated December 11, 1951 stated Roadways vehicles exempt under notification No. 252/-IX-209/ 10 dated March 16, 1925.

anchor.surface_text: The Government order to which reference has been made in the two judgments of the High Court runs as follows Subject Exemption from payment of toll.

facts.text: Notification dated March 16, 1925 exempts all persons, animals and vehicles crossing by public ferry when employed or transmitted on the public or District Board service.

anchor.surface_text: That notification reads thus The following shall be exempt from the payment of tolls All persons animals and vehicles crossing any river by a public ferry when employed

facts.text: At the date of 1925 notification, the State was not running any bus services in United Provinces.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly at that date the State was notrunning any bus services in the United Provinces  not the State of Uttar Pradesh .

facts.text: Roadways department of U.P. Government is running a profit making activity.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed before us that the Roadways department of the Government of U. P. is running a profit making and a profitable activity

facts.text: Court finds Roadways buses not employed on public service, not entitled to exemption under 1925 notification.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, therefore, we find it impossible to hold that its vehicles crossing over ferries can be regarded as crossing on public service.

facts.text: Since no exemption, question of abatement of rent does not arise.

anchor.surface_text: They are, therefore, not entitled to any exemption under the notification of March 15, 192 5. Since they are not entitled to any exemption the question

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside judgments of Division Bench and single judge, directs writ of mandamus to pay full tolls for Roadways buses crossings from March 16, 1954 to licence expiry.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Division Bench as well as of the single judge of the High Court of Allahabad and direct that a writ in the nature of mandamus shall issue to the respondents directing them to pay to the appellant full tolls with respect to every crossing of the, Roadways buses over the ferry between March 16, 1954, and the date on which the licence in favour of the appellant expired.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 8, 1962 by MUDHOLKAR, J.

concepts.unlisted_description: Levy of tolls at govt-fixed rates; power to declare exemptions; abatement of rent if declaration after ferry tolls lease under s.8

anchor.surface_text: Section 15 of the Northern India Ferries Act, 1878 runs thus Toll., according to such rates as are from time to time fixed by the State Government, shall be levied on all persons, animals, vehi- cles and other things crossing any river by a public ferry and number employed or transmitted on the public service Provided that the State Government may from time to- time, declare that any persons, animals, vehicles or other things shall be exempt from payment of such tolls. Where the tolls of a ferry have been let under section 8, any such declaration, if made after the date of the lease, shall entitle the lessee to such abatement of the rent payable in respect of the tolls as may be fixed by the Commissioner of the division or such other officer as the State Government may, from time to time, appoint in this behalf by Dame or virtue of his office.

issues.text: Before the question of allowing abatement of rent or licence fee can arise it must first be established that there was a valid exemption with respect to any vehicles etc., under s. 15 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to the section confers upon the State Government power to declare from time to time any , persons, animals, vehicles etc., exempt from payment of such tolls. Before the question of allowing abatement of rent or licence fee can arise it must first be established that there was a valid exemption with respect to any vehicles etc., under s. 15 of the Act.

holdings.text: Roadways buses are not entitled to exemption from ferry tolls under the 1925 notification as they are not employed on public service.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed before us that the Roadways department of the Government of U. P. is running a profit making and a profitable activity by excluding every kind of competition. In the circumstances, therefore, we find it impossible to hold that its vehicles crossing over ferries can be regarded as crossing on public service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Profit-making commercial bus service run by state indistinguishable from private operators; historical context shows no state buses in 1925; public service limited to sovereign/governmental functions, not commercial activities with profit motive.

holdings.text: Roadways buses not exempt under notification of March 16, 1925.

anchor.surface_text: They are, therefore, not entitled to any exemption under the notification of March 15, 192 5.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from h1; applies plain language of notification to facts of commercial operation.

holdings.text: Since no exemption, question of abatement of rent under proviso to s.15 does not arise.

anchor.surface_text: Since they are not entitled to any exemption the question of abatement of rent does not arise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical prerequisite under s.15: abatement conditional on valid declaration of exemption; none exists.

holdings.text: 1951 G.O. does not confer exemption; merely opines on 1925 notification which does not apply to roadways buses.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that this order, if what appears to be merely a communication addressed to certain authorities can be regarded as a Government order, does not, itself confer any exemption with respect to the buses run by the U. P. Roadways but sets out the opinion of the Government that such buses must be regarded as being exempted under a notification of March 16, 1925 issued under s. 15 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: G.O. not a declaration under s.15; relies on inapplicable 1925 notification.

holdings.text: Writ of mandamus under Art.226 directing payment of full tolls issues to respondents for Roadways buses crossings from March 16, 1954 to licence expiry.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Division Bench as well as of the single judge of the High Court of Allahabad and direct that a writ in the nature of mandamus shall issue to the respondents directing them to pay to the appellant full tolls with respect to every crossing of the, Roadways buses over the ferry between March 16, 1954, and the date on which the licence in favour of the appellant expired.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition contains general prayer for other reliefs, not amended; appropriate relief grantable despite arguments confined to abatement due to misunderstanding of law.

holdings.text: Plying stage carriage buses commercially, even by government, is not public service if run with profit motive.

anchor.surface_text: What the notification exempts is a vehicle crossing the river on public or district board service. Could it be said that plying motor buses by way of commercial activity is running it on a public service? It is undoubtedly not easy to define what is public service and each activity has to be considered by itself for deciding whether it is carried on as a public service or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes sovereign functions from commercial undertakings; profit motive and competition with private operators key; beneficial public utility insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed before us that the Roadways department of the Government of U. P. is running a profit making and a profitable activity by excluding every kind of competition. In the circumstances, therefore, we find it impossible to hold that its vehicles crossing over ferries can be regarded as crossing on public service.

In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Division Bench as well as of the single judge of the High Court of Allahabad and direct that a writ in the nature of mandamus shall issue to the respondents directing them to pay to the appellant full tolls with respect to every crossing of the

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that this order, if what appears to be merely a communication addressed to certain authorities can be regarded as a Government order, does not, itself confer any exemption with respect to the buses run by the U. P. Roadways but sets out the opinion of the Government that such buses must be regarded as being exempted under a notification of March 16, 1925 issued under s. 15 of the Act.

In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Division Bench as well as of the single judge of the High Court of Allahabad and direct that a writ in the nature of mandamus shall issue to the respondents directing them to pay to the appellant full tolls with respect to every crossing of the

anchor.surface_text: In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Division Bench as well as of the single judge of the High Court of Allahabad and direct that a writ in the nature of mandamus shall issue to the respondents directing them to pay to the appellant full tolls with respect to every crossing of the, Roadways buses over the ferry between March 16, 1954, and the date on which the licence in favour of the appellant expired.

In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Division Bench as well as of the single judge of the High Court of Allahabad and direct that a writ in the nature of mandamus shall issue to the respondents directing them to pay to the appellant full tolls with respect to every crossing of the
ubtedly number easy to define what is public service and each activity has to be companysidered by itself for deciding whether it is carried on as a p

anchor.surface_text: What the notification exempts is a vehicle crossing the river on public or district board service. Could it be said that plying motor buses by way of commercial activity is running it on a public service? It is undoubtedly not easy to define what is public service and each activity has to be considered by itself for deciding whether it is carried on as a public service or not.

In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Division Bench as well as of the single judge of the High Court of Allahabad and direct that a writ in the nature of mandamus shall issue to the respondents directing them to pay to the appellant full tolls with respect to every crossing of the
